"Enlarge")

A depiction of the "long serpent" rocket launcher from the 11th century book
_[Wujing Zongyao](/wiki/Wujing_Zongyao "Wujing Zongyao")_. The holes in the
frame are designed to keep the fire arrows separate.

This article gives a concise **[timeline](/wiki/Timeline "Timeline") of
[rocket](/wiki/Rocket "Rocket") and [missile](/wiki/Missile "Missile")
[technology](/wiki/Technology "Technology")**.

## Contents

  * 1 11th century
  * 2 17th century-19th century
  * 3 20th century
  * 4 21st century
  * 5 See also
  * 6 References

## 11th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_rocket_and_missile_technology&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: 11th century")]

  * 11th century AD - The first documented record of [gunpowder](/wiki/Gunpowder "Gunpowder") and the [fire arrow](/wiki/Fire_arrow "Fire arrow"), an early form of rocketry, appears in the Chinese text _[Wujing Zongyao](/wiki/Wujing_Zongyao "Wujing Zongyao")_.

## 17th century-19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_rocket_and_missile_technology&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: 17th century-19th century")]

  * 1633 - [Lagâri Hasan Çelebi](/wiki/Lag%C3%A2ri_Hasan_%C3%87elebi "Lagâri Hasan Çelebi") launched a 7-winged rocket using 50 okka (140 lbs) of gunpowder from Sarayburnu, the point below [Topkapı Palace](/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace "Topkapı Palace") in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul").[1]
  * 1650 - _Artis Magnae Artilleriae pars prima_ ("Great Art of Artillery, the First Part") is printed in Amsterdam, about a year before the death of its author, [Kazimierz Siemienowicz](/wiki/Kazimierz_Siemienowicz "Kazimierz Siemienowicz").
  * 1664 - A "space rocket" is imagined as a future technology to be studied in France and its drawing is ordered by [French](/wiki/France "France") finance minister [Colbert](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Colbert "Jean-Baptiste Colbert"); designed by [Le Brun](/wiki/Charles_Le_Brun "Charles Le Brun") on a [Gobelins](/wiki/Gobelins_manufactory "Gobelins manufactory") tapestry [2] (see: [French space program](/wiki/French_space_program "French space program"))
  * 1798 - [Tipu Sultan](/wiki/Tipu_Sultan "Tipu Sultan"), the King of the state of [Mysore](/wiki/Mysore "Mysore") in India, develops and uses iron rockets against the British Army (see [Mysorean rockets](/wiki/Mysorean_rockets "Mysorean rockets")).
  * 1801 - The British Army develops the [Congreve rocket](/wiki/Congreve_rocket "Congreve rocket") based on weapons used against them by [Tipu Sultan](/wiki/Tipu_Sultan "Tipu Sultan").
  * 1806 - Claude Ruggieri, an Italian living in France, launched animals on rockets and recovered them using parachutes. He was prevented from launching a child by police.[3]
  * 1813 - "A Treatise on the Motion of Rockets" by [William Moore](/wiki/William_Moore_\(British_mathematician\) "William Moore \(British mathematician\)") – first appearance of the [rocket equation](/wiki/Rocket_equation "Rocket equation")
  * 1818 - [Henry Trengrouse](/wiki/Henry_Trengrouse "Henry Trengrouse") demonstrates his rocket apparatus for projecting a lifeline from a wrecked ship to the shore, later widely adopted
  * 1844 - [William Hale](/wiki/William_Hale_\(British_inventor\) "William Hale \(British inventor\)") invents the [spin-stabilized](/wiki/Spin-stabilisation "Spin-stabilisation") rocket
  * 1861 - [William Leitch](/wiki/William_Leitch_\(scientist\) "William Leitch \(scientist\)") publishes an essay "A Journey Through Space" (later published in his book God's Glory in the Heavens (1862)), introducing the concept of using rockets to propel a vehicle carrying people into space, to visit the Moon and other planets.
  * 1865 - [Jules Verne](/wiki/Jules_Verne "Jules Verne") publishes _[From the Earth to the Moon](/wiki/From_the_Earth_to_the_Moon "From the Earth to the Moon")_ as a humorous science fantasy story about a [space gun](/wiki/Space_gun "Space gun") launching a manned spacecraft equipped with rockets for landing on the Moon, but eventually used for another [orbital maneuver](/wiki/Orbital_maneuver "Orbital maneuver").

## 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_rocket_and_missile_technology&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 20th century")]

  * 1902 - French cinema pioneer [Georges Méliès](/wiki/Georges_M%C3%A9li%C3%A8s "Georges Méliès") directs _[A Trip to the Moon](/wiki/A_Trip_to_the_Moon "A Trip to the Moon")_ , the first film about space travel.
  * 1903 - [Konstantin Tsiolkovsky](/wiki/Konstantin_Tsiolkovsky "Konstantin Tsiolkovsky") begins a series of papers discussing the use of [rocketry](/wiki/Rocket "Rocket") to reach outer space, [space suits](/wiki/Space_suit "Space suit"), and colonization of the [solar system](/wiki/Solar_system "Solar system"). Two key points discussed in his works are [liquid fuels](/wiki/Liquid_fuel "Liquid fuel") and [staging](/wiki/Staging_\(rocketry\) "Staging \(rocketry\)").
  * 1913 - Without knowing the work of Russian mathematician [Konstantin Tsiolkovsky](/wiki/Konstantin_Tsiolkovsky "Konstantin Tsiolkovsky"), French engineer [Robert Esnault-Pelterie](/wiki/Robert_Esnault-Pelterie "Robert Esnault-Pelterie") derived the equations for space flight, produced a paper that presented the [rocket equation](/wiki/Rocket_equation "Rocket equation") and calculated the energies required to reach the Moon and nearby planets.[4]
  * 1922 - [Hermann Oberth](/wiki/Hermann_Oberth "Hermann Oberth") publishes his scientific work about rocketry and space exploration: _Die Rakete zu den Planetenräumen_ ("By Rocket into Planetary Space").
  * 1924 - [Society for Studies of Interplanetary Travel](/wiki/Society_for_Studies_of_Interplanetary_Travel "Society for Studies of Interplanetary Travel") founded in [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") by Konstantin Tsiolkovsky, [Friedrich Zander](/wiki/Friedrich_Zander "Friedrich Zander") and 200 other space and rocket experts
  * 1926 - [Robert Goddard](/wiki/Robert_Goddard_\(scientist\) "Robert Goddard \(scientist\)") launches the first liquid fuel rocket.
  * 1927 - [Verein für Raumschiffahrt](/wiki/Verein_f%C3%BCr_Raumschiffahrt "Verein für Raumschiffahrt") (VfR - "Spaceflight Society") founded in Germany.
  * 1929 - _[Woman in the Moon](/wiki/Woman_in_the_Moon "Woman in the Moon")_ , considered to be one of the first "serious" science fiction films.
  * 1931 - [Friedrich Schmiedl](/wiki/Friedrich_Schmiedl "Friedrich Schmiedl") attempts the first [rocket mail](/wiki/Rocket_mail "Rocket mail") service in [Austria](/wiki/Austria "Austria")
  * 1935 - [Emilio Herrera Linares](/wiki/Emilio_Herrera_Linares "Emilio Herrera Linares") from [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain") designed and made the first full-pressured astronaut suit, called the escafandra estratonáutica. The Russians then used a model of Herrera's suit when first flying into space of which the Americans would then later adopt when creating their own space program.
  * 1937 - [Peenemünde Army Research Center](/wiki/Peenem%C3%BCnde_Army_Research_Center "Peenemünde Army Research Center") founded in Germany
  * 1938 - The Projectile Development Establishment founded at [Fort Halstead](/wiki/Fort_Halstead "Fort Halstead") for the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")'s research into military [solid-fuel rockets](/wiki/Solid-propellant_rocket "Solid-propellant rocket").
  * 1939 - [Katyusha](/wiki/Katyusha_rocket_launcher "Katyusha rocket launcher") multiple rocket launchers ([Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Катюша) are a type of [rocket artillery](/wiki/Rocket_artillery "Rocket artillery") first built and fielded by the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union").
  * 1941 - French rocket [EA-41](/w/index.php?title=EA-41_\(rocket\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "EA-41 \(rocket\) \(page does not exist\)") is launched, being the first European [liquid propellant](/wiki/Rocket_propellant "Rocket propellant") working rocket[5]
  * 1941 - Jet Assisted Take Off [JATO](/wiki/JATO "JATO") installed on US Army Air Corp [Ercoupe](/wiki/ERCO_Ercoupe "ERCO Ercoupe") aircraft occurred on 12 August in March Field, California.
  * 1942 - [Wernher von Braun](/wiki/Wernher_von_Braun "Wernher von Braun") and [Walter Dornberger](/wiki/Walter_Dornberger "Walter Dornberger") launch the first [V-2 rocket](/wiki/V-2_rocket "V-2 rocket") at [Peenemünde](/wiki/Peenem%C3%BCnde "Peenemünde") in northern Germany.
  * 1942 - A V-2 rocket reaches an altitude of 85 km.
  * 1944 - The V-2 rocket [MW 18014](/w/index.php?title=MW_18014&action=edit&redlink=1 "MW 18014 \(page does not exist\)") reaches an altitude of 176 km, becoming the first man-made object in [space](/wiki/Outer_space "Outer space").
  * 1945 - [Lothar Sieber](/wiki/Lothar_Sieber "Lothar Sieber") dies after the first vertical take-off manned rocket flight in a [Bachem Ba 349](/wiki/Bachem_Ba_349 "Bachem Ba 349") "Natter"
  * 1945 - [Operation Paperclip](/wiki/Operation_Paperclip "Operation Paperclip") takes 1,600 German rocket scientists and technicians to the United States
  * 1945 - [Operation Osoaviakhim](/wiki/Operation_Osoaviakhim "Operation Osoaviakhim") takes 2,000 German rocket scientists and technicians to the Soviet Union
  * 1946 - First flight of the [Nike missile](/wiki/Nike_missile "Nike missile"), later the first operational [surface-to-air guided missile](/wiki/Surface-to-air_missile "Surface-to-air missile")
  * 1947 - [Chuck Yeager](/wiki/Chuck_Yeager "Chuck Yeager") achieves the first manned [supersonic](/wiki/Supersonic "Supersonic") flight in a [Bell X-1](/wiki/Bell_X-1 "Bell X-1") rocket-powered aircraft
  * 1949 - [Willy Ley](/wiki/Willy_Ley "Willy Ley") publishes _The Conquest of Space_
  * 1952 - 22 May, French [Véronique 1](/wiki/V%C3%A9ronique_\(rocket\) "Véronique \(rocket\)") rocket is launched from the [Algerian desert](/wiki/French_Algeria "French Algeria").
  * 1952 - Wernher von Braun discusses the technical details of a manned exploration of [Mars](/wiki/Mars "Mars") in _[Das Marsprojekt](/wiki/Das_Marsprojekt "Das Marsprojekt")_.
  * 1953 - Colliers Magazine publishes a series of articles on man's future in space, igniting the interest of people around the world. The series includes numerous articles by Ley and von Braun, illustrated by Chesley Bonestell.
  * 1956 - First launch of [PGM-17 Thor](/wiki/PGM-17_Thor "PGM-17 Thor"), the first US ballistic missile and forerunner of the [Delta space launch rockets](/wiki/Delta_\(rocket_family\) "Delta \(rocket family\)")
  * 1957 - Launch of the first [ICBM](/wiki/ICBM "ICBM"), the [USSR](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")'s [R-7 (8K71)](/wiki/R-7_rocket "R-7 rocket"), known to [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") as the SS-6 _Sapwood_.
  * 1957 - The USSR launches [Sputnik 1](/wiki/Sputnik_1 "Sputnik 1"), the first artificial satellite.
  * 1958 - The U.S. launches [Explorer 1](/wiki/Explorer_1 "Explorer 1"), the first American artificial satellite, on a [Jupiter-C](/wiki/Jupiter-C "Jupiter-C") rocket.
  * 1958 - US launches their first ICBM, the [Atlas](/wiki/Atlas_\(missile\) "Atlas \(missile\)")-B (the Atlas-A was a test article only).
  * 1961 - the USSR launches [Vostok 1](/wiki/Vostok_1 "Vostok 1"), [Yuri Gagarin](/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin "Yuri Gagarin") reached a height of 327 km above Earth and was the first man to orbit Earth.
  * 1961 - US, a [Mercury](/wiki/Mercury_program "Mercury program") capsule named [Freedom 7](/wiki/Freedom_7 "Freedom 7") with [Alan B. Shepard](/wiki/Alan_Shepard "Alan Shepard"), spacecraft was launched by a [Redstone rocket](/wiki/Redstone_\(rocket\) "Redstone \(rocket\)") on a ballistic trajectory [suborbital flight](/wiki/Suborbital_flight "Suborbital flight").
  * 1962 - The US launches Mercury MA-6 ([Friendship 7](/wiki/Friendship_7 "Friendship 7")) on an [Atlas D](/wiki/Atlas_\(rocket_family\) "Atlas \(rocket family\)") booster, [John Glenn](/wiki/John_Glenn "John Glenn") finally puts America in orbit.
  * 1963 - The USSR launches [Vostok 6](/wiki/Vostok_6 "Vostok 6"), [Valentina Tereshkova](/wiki/Valentina_Tereshkova "Valentina Tereshkova") was the first woman (and first civilian) to orbit Earth. She remained in space for nearly three days and orbited the Earth 48 times.
  * 1963 - US [X-15](/wiki/X-15 "X-15") rocket-plane, the first reusable manned spacecraft (suborbital) reaches space, pioneering reusability, carried launch and glide landings.
  * 1965 - USSR Proton rocket, highly successful launch vehicle with notable payloads, Salyut 6 & Salyut 7, Mir & ISS components
  * 1965 - Robert Salked investigates various single stage to orbit spaceplane concepts[6][7][8]
  * 1966 - USSR [Luna 9](/wiki/Luna_9 "Luna 9"), the first soft landing on the [Moon](/wiki/Moon "Moon")
  * 1966 - USSR launches [Soyuz](/wiki/Soyuz_spacecraft "Soyuz spacecraft") spacecraft, longest-running series of spacecraft, eventually serving Soviet, Russian and International space missions.
  * 1969 - US _[Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11")_ , first men on the Moon, first lunar surface extravehicular activity.
  * 1981 - US [space shuttle](/wiki/Space_shuttle "Space shuttle") pioneers reusability and glide landings
  * 1998 - US [Deep Space 1](/wiki/Deep_Space_1 "Deep Space 1") is first deep space mission to use an [ion thruster](/wiki/Ion_thruster "Ion thruster") for propulsion.
  * 1998 - Russia launch [Zarya](/wiki/Zarya "Zarya") module which is the first part of the [International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station").

## 21st
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_rocket_and_missile_technology&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: 21st century")]

  * 2001 - Russian [Soyuz](/wiki/Soyuz_spacecraft "Soyuz spacecraft") spacecraft sent the first space tourist [Dennis Tito](/wiki/Dennis_Tito "Dennis Tito") to [International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station").[9]
  * 2004 - US-based, first privately developed, manned (suborbital) spaceflight, [SpaceShipOne](/wiki/SpaceShipOne "SpaceShipOne") demonstrates reusability.[10]
  * 2008 - [SpaceX](/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX")—with their [Falcon 1](/wiki/Falcon_1 "Falcon 1") rocket—became the first [private entity](/wiki/Private_spaceflight "Private spaceflight") to successfully launch a [rocket](/wiki/Launch_vehicle "Launch vehicle") into [orbit](/wiki/Orbital_spaceflight "Orbital spaceflight").[11]
  * 2012 - The [SpaceX Dragon](/wiki/SpaceX_Dragon "SpaceX Dragon") [space capsule](/wiki/Space_capsule "Space capsule")—launched aboard a [Falcon 9](/wiki/Falcon_9_v1.0 "Falcon 9 v1.0") launch vehicle—was the first private [spacecraft](/wiki/Spacecraft "Spacecraft") to successfully dock with another spacecraft, and was also the first private capsule to dock at the [International Space Station](/wiki/International_Space_Station "International Space Station").[12]
  * 2014 - First booster rocket returning from an [orbital trajectory](/wiki/Orbital_spaceflight "Orbital spaceflight") to achieve a zero-velocity-at-zero-altitude [propulsive](/wiki/Rocket_propulsion "Rocket propulsion") [vertical landing](/wiki/VTVL "VTVL"). The first-stage booster of [Falcon 9 Flight 9](/wiki/Falcon_9_Flight_9 "Falcon 9 Flight 9") made the first successful controlled ocean soft touchdown of a liquid-rocket-engine orbital booster on April 18, 2014.[13][14]
  * 2015 - [SpaceX](/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX")'s [Falcon 9 Flight 20](/wiki/Falcon_9_Flight_20 "Falcon 9 Flight 20") was the first time that the first stage of an orbital rocket made a successful return and [vertical landing](/wiki/VTVL "VTVL").[15]
  * 2017 - [SpaceX](/wiki/SpaceX "SpaceX")'s [Falcon 9](/wiki/Falcon_9 "Falcon 9") [SES-10](/wiki/SES-10 "SES-10") was the first time a used orbital rocket made a successful return [16]
  * 2018 - The [Electron](/wiki/Electron_\(rocket\) "Electron \(rocket\)") rocket was the first New-Zealand rocket to achieve orbit. The rocket is also unique in using an [electric pump-fed engine](/wiki/Electric_pump-fed_engine "Electric pump-fed engine"). The rocket also carried an additional satellite payload called "Humanity Star", a 1-meter-wide (3 ft) carbon fiber sphere made up of 65 panels that reflect the Sun's light.[17]
